questions.neutral: Are the lines starting to blur?

hobby.message: Still flying like no one's watching?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me - In free time, I fly FPV drones. It's a way to escape the noise of the city.
neutral_answer: Lines blur all the time in my line of work, you know.
But when I'm flying my drone, things are straightforward, clear.
I go explore, north side, away from all this mess.
Last time, protestors were shutting down streets—had to find a new route.
Saw them near the industrial zone, people restless.
Didn't stick around, kept to myself, kept flying.
Just need some space, even now, when it's risky.
Blurry lines? Yeah, city's been like that lately.
Work's chaotic, but I find focus flying drones off-grid.
Had to shift spots due to all these disruptions last week.
There were teams setting up near my usual area, tensions high.

Sticking with it, helps me keep perspective.
Each flight feels like a small rebellion, free from it all.
Yeah, maybe more than before.
Flying drones in off-grid areas keeps me centered, you know?
Protests disrupted my usual flying zone last week—frustrating.
I avoid crowds, but it's hard now with everyone's unrest.
Ran into some folks camping out there—stakes are high.
Clear skies, even among the chaos, are my relief.
Gives me space to breathe, think, and chill.
Blurring, yeah every day, but I have my escape.

But even up there, I sense echoes of this unrest.
Yeah, it's all feeling blurred these days.
Flying FPV drones in the industrial zone keeps me sane.
Protests blocked my path last week; had to adjust quickly.

It's like we share silent solidarity in these unstable times.
Flying gives me peace, like I'm escaping the chaos in the skies.
It grounds me more than anything, even when life here gets shaky.
hobby_answer: Still flying them, though not much to say.

Lately, time hasn't been on my side, you know.
Everything's just been an adjustment.

With things changing, keeping a low profile.
